Posts.EditableText:
Is  it possible to do this:

1. Make a Notepad/Wordpad/Savefile in the Quest file
2. Publish to txtadventures.co.uk
3. When downloaded, you can read the files and use the savefile
4. But when online, no luck.

One more thing:

Can I have the HTML of the online player? The desktop player version looks too boring. And when I use it, where should I call it?
Posts.HTML:
Is it possible to do this:

1. Make a Notepad/Wordpad/Savefile in the Quest file
2. Publish to txtadventures.co.uk
3. When downloaded, you can read the files and use the savefile
4. But when online, no luck.

One more thing:

Can I have the HTML of the online player? The desktop player version looks too boring. And when I use it, where should I call it?

Posts.EditableText: [quote="sonic102":gfie0vk5] 3. When downloaded, you can read the files and use the savefile [/quote:gfie0vk5] Savegame is not possible, but you can create a walkthrough Reading files? Do you mean reading ingame or just the possibility to open these files with an editor and read the content? [quote="sonic102":gfie0vk5] Can I have the HTML of the online player? The desktop player version looks too boring. And when I use it, where should I call it?[/quote:gfie0vk5] The code of the online player is open source and you can download it here: http://quest.codeplex.com/SourceControl/list/changesets. But then you have to understand the code and you must install it on your internetserver. You can't just start it like an .exe
Posts.HTML:
sonic102 wrote:
3. When downloaded, you can read the files and use the savefile

Savegame is not possible, but you can create a walkthrough
Reading files? Do you mean reading ingame or just the possibility to open these files with an editor and read the content?

sonic102 wrote:
Can I have the HTML of the online player? The desktop player version looks too boring. And when I use it, where should I call it?

The code of the online player is open source and you can download it here: http://quest.codeplex.com/SourceControl/list/changesets. But then you have to understand the code and you must install it on your internetserver. You can't just start it like an .exe

Posts.EditableText:
[quote="sonic102":2u8jfir7]
1. Open it outside the game.
[/quote:2u8jfir7]

No, that's not possible. All files are in a .quest-file, so the user must extract the files from this zip

[quote="sonic102":2u8jfir7]
I used the twohalves.js and html script in my game, but an error pops up.

Line: 23
Char: 36
Err: mising ";"

I don't need to give the js file because it is in codeplex, right?[/quote:2u8jfir7]
No. The files in codeplex are correct (no bugs), so there must be a change that causes this message. Perhaps you could append the complete game?
Posts.HTML:

No, that's not possible. All files are in a .quest-file, so the user must extract the files from this zip

No. The files in codeplex are correct (no bugs), so there must be a change that causes this message. Perhaps you could append the complete game?

Posts.EditableText: It would be a pretty huge security flaw if Quest gave you "carte blanche" to just create and write to files on your system, so I wouldn't expect that to be a feature that's going to be added either. I'm curious though, what are you doing in your game that would require this as a feature? I'm quite interested to know.
Posts.HTML:
It would be a pretty huge security flaw if Quest gave you "carte blanche" to just create and write to files on your system, so I wouldn't expect that to be a feature that's going to be added either.

I'm curious though, what are you doing in your game that would require this as a feature? I'm quite interested to know.

Posts.EditableText: I don't think he wants to create files while playing a game. I thought he was speaking of a credit file or a instruction file the player could open and read before playing a game.
Posts.HTML: I don't think he wants to create files while playing a game. I thought he was speaking of a credit file or a instruction file the player could open and read before playing a game.

Posts.EditableText: Ah, I see. The wording was very confusing.
